title: How a Pressure Cooker Works
summary: An India-classic device that demonstrates Boyle's law, vapour pressure, and heat transfer.
content:
Case Study: The Pressure Cooker

A pressure cooker is found in virtually every Indian kitchen. It cooks food in a fraction of the normal time — dal in 10 minutes instead of 45 minutes. How?

The Physics

Water normally boils at 100°C. But inside a sealed pressure cooker, steam cannot escape, so pressure builds up above atmospheric pressure. At higher pressure, the boiling point of water rises — typically to about 120°C. Food cooks faster at higher temperature.

Key Concepts Applied

  • Boyle's Law: Pressure × Volume = constant (for fixed temperature and amount of gas)
  • Phase Transition: Steam formation depends on both temperature and pressure
  • Heat Conduction: Aluminium body conducts heat from gas stove to water efficiently

Safety Note

The safety valve releases excess steam if pressure gets too high — an excellent example of pressure relief engineering. Never force open a hot pressure cooker!
